CLINTON_199_2.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: Does the relationship between the United States and Muslim nations, particularly in the Middle East, suffer from Donald's consistently negative rhetoric towards Muslims?
Does the president's rhetoric towards Muslim communities, as exemplified by his consistent insults, hinder or facilitate the collection of intelligence from these communities?
Can we effectively gather intelligence from Muslim nations and communities while simultaneously being insulted by Donald's rhetoric, which may prove to be an intelligence benefit?

Does the approach of increasing intelligence gathering through cooperation with Muslim nations and communities, as advocated by Clinton, outweigh the potential risks associated with Donald's rhetoric towards Muslims?

CLINTON_1_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: Can the creation of profit-sharing programs and affordable family benefits, such as paid family leave and debt-free college, effectively cause an increase in productivity and employee satisfaction among the working class, rather than solely benefiting executives at the top?
Does Clinton's emphasis on shared profits and corporate loopholes adequately address the complexities of economic inequality and wealth disparity?
How does Clinton's emphasis on corporate loopholes and the wealthy paying their fair share relate to her broader economic and social policies?
How can a president effectively balance the needs of the wealthy and the struggles of the working class while addressing the corporate loopholes and the responsibilities of the presidency?

CLINTON_21.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: What effect did the economic policies of the past have on the current economic situation of the United States?
Does the notion that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese align with the views of independent experts?

What makes Clinton's claim that his policies are superior to Trump's because they address climate change as a real issue rather than a hoax more credible than Trump's claim that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese?
Does President Clinton's assertion that independent experts support his clean energy proposal hold up to scrutiny in the face of his own administration's record on the issue?

CLINTON_223_1.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: Did the invocation of Article 5 by NATO after 9/11 serve as a direct cause for the United States to have a stronger military presence in Afghanistan, and was it a sufficient cause for the United States to take a stronger stance against Iran's nuclear program?
Does the invocation of Article 5 by NATO after 9/11 imply a precedent for similar collective military action against other nations with nuclear capabilities, such as Iran?
How can the analogy between the NATO alliance's response to the 9/11 attacks and the US response to the Iranian nuclear threat be applied to other global security crises?
Does the NATO alliance's invocation of Article 5 in response to 9/11 justify the US-led military action in Afghanistan, or is it an example of a more nuanced approach to international cooperation?

CLINTON_223_2.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: Can imposing sanctions on Iran without international cooperation lead to effective diplomatic solutions?
Does Clinton's experience and diplomacy in dealing with Iran, as described, demonstrate effective leadership and coalition-building skills, or is it a flawed example of poor judgment?

Can the effectiveness of Clinton's sanctions on Iran, which led to a deal without firing a single shot, be considered a better example of diplomacy and coalition-building compared to other foreign policy decisions made by the former president?

CLINTON_225.input: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

CLINTON_244_2.input:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: Does President Clinton's lack of a clear alternative plan for defeating ISIS undermine his ability to lead the world with strength and in accordance with American values?
What specific, tangible, and measurable alternatives does Clinton propose to the deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before?

Can a president who has no clear alternative to a successful deal and no clear plan to defeat ISIS truly be relied upon as a leader who will further peace and prosperity?

CLINTON_25.input:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

CLINTON_37.input:
CLINTON: " Some of them I voted for
The biggest one, a multinational one known as CAFTA, I voted against
I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals
let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy
it is a part of it
I'm going to have a special prosecutor
We're going to enforce the trade deals we have, and we're going to hold people accountable
When I was secretary of state, we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent
We increased them to China 50 percent
 know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs"

CLINTON: "There are different views about what's good for our country, our economy, and our leadership in the world

CLINTON_57.input:
CLINTON: "you have no plan
I have written a book about it. It's called "Stronger Together."
You can pick it up tomorrow at a bookstore
we need to have strong growth , fair growth , sustained growth
We also have to look at how we help families balance the responsibilities at home and the responsibilities at business
we have a very robust set of plans
people have looked at both of our plans , have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs , and explode the debt which would have a recession"

cqs.cq: Can the author's claim that their plan would create 10 million jobs and the other plan would lose 3.5 million jobs be supported by evidence from credible sources?

CLINTON_66.input:
CLINTON: "what I have proposed would not add a penny to the debt
 your plans would add $ 5 trillion to the debt
What I have proposed would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses
What I have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy
they have made all the gains in the economy
it 's time that the wealthy and corporations paid their fair share to support this country"

cqs.cq: Would the proposed tax increases on the wealthy and corporations, as suggested by Clinton, actually result in a decrease in the national debt, or would it merely redistribute the burden of debt from one group to another?

CLINTON_6_1.input:
CLINTON: "we are 5 percent of the world 's population ; we have to trade with the other 95 percent
we need to have smart , fair trade deals
We also , though , need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions
the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again
it would be the most extreme version , the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we 've ever had
trumped-up trickle-down , because that 's exactly what it would be
That is not how we grow the economy
We just have a different view about what 's best for growing the economy , how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes
we come at it from somewhat different perspectives
Donald was very fortunate in his life , and that 's all to his benefit"

cqs.cq: What effect does the adoption of trickle-down economics, as described by Donald, have on the economic growth and job creation in the country?
Does the President's plan to reward work over financial transactions align with his claim that his tax plan is the most extreme version of trickle-down economics?
Does CLINTON's assertion that the kind of tax plan proposed by Donald would be "trickle-down economics all over again" accurately reflect the potential consequences of such a policy?

Does the proposed tax system by Donald, which would provide the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country, align with the goal of growing the economy and producing jobs and rising incomes?

CLINTON_6_2.input:
CLINTON: "He started his business with $ 14 million , borrowed from his father
he really believes that the more you help wealthy people , the better off we 'll be and that everything will work out from there
I do n't buy that
I have a different experience
My father was a small-businessman
He worked really hard
He printed drapery fabrics on long tables, where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going
what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future
the better we will be off and the better we'll grow
That's the kind of economy I want us to see again"

cqs.cq: Does the experience of Clinton's father in running a small business, where he printed drapery fabrics, align with his claim that the more we can help wealthy people, the better off we'll be?

CLINTON: "I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit

CLINTON_92.input:
CLINTON: "it is
trumped-up trickle-down
Trickle-down did not work
It got us into the mess we were in , in 2008 and 2009
Slashing taxes on the wealthy has n't worked
a lot of really smart , wealthy people know that
they are saying , hey , we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class
I do n't think top-down works in America
building the middle class , investing in the middle class , making college debt-free so more young people can get their education , helping people refinance their—their debt from college at a lower rate
Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy
Broad-based , inclusive growth is what we need in America , not more advantages for people at the very top"

cqs.cq: Can the trickle-down economic approach, as described by Clinton, be effectively implemented in America without creating more economic inequality?

CL: "Well, both sides of the transaction suffer as a result of ignoring moral hazard
because moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing
And if you suppress it, then in fact you're in a situation where the wealth that you look like you're generating is fool’s gold, not real wealth at all."

Doctor-Mom_205.input:
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: Would a full ban of peanut products on any airline be effective in preventing life-threatening reactions when considering the potential consequences of restricting access to food choices, which could lead to a lack of available options for passengers?
Does the elimination of peanuts from airline products align with the broader societal benefits, considering the potential risks and the availability of alternative food options?

Would a blanket ban on peanut products on airlines be more effective than restricting them to certain flights, considering the potential risks of cross-contamination and the presence of alternative food options?

Would a full ban of peanut products on any airline be a more effective measure than the current buffer zone approach in preventing life-threatening peanut reactions, considering the potential impact on the airline industry and the safety of passengers?

FoodAllergyMom_199_1.input:
FoodAllergyMom: "My child is 2 years old and he is severely allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, egg and milk.
My son has reacted to airborne particles from someone opening a bag of nuts near him.
My husband and I used to be world traveler's and dreamed of traveling with our son.
It is heartbreaking to think that our child will not get to experience the world, or if he does it may cost him his life.
What about when he gets older and his job requires him to fly across the country in a weekend?
Should he have to risk his life so he can work in his possible future dream job?
This is a disability, no question about it.
We are talking about being in the air with peanut particles being circulated through the cabin and possible no place to land for hours.
An EpiPen only last 15 minutes.
Peanut allergy is unpredictable.
The first reaction could be mild
and the second could cause your blood pressure to drop like a rocket, your throat to close up and your heart to stop beating."

cqs.cq: What are the long-term implications of a child's severe food allergy on their future career choices and travel opportunities, particularly when considering the unpredictability of their reactions and the limitations of emergency response measures like EpiPens?

Does the risk of peanut exposure in the workplace outweigh the potential benefits of allowing children with severe peanut allergies to pursue their career goals, particularly in industries that require frequent air travel?
Is the analogy between the risks associated with flying and the risks associated with having a peanut allergy an accurate representation of the severity and unpredictability of the child's condition?
Should a child with severe food allergies be prioritized over the needs of the airline industry and the demands of a job when it comes to accommodating their needs in the workplace?

Frequent-Flyer_157.input:
Frequent-Flyer: "I have sympathy for those with peanut allergies,
but banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation seems to go too far.
Perhaps advocacy groups for those who are peanutallergic will approach the major carriers to voluntarily set aside seating blocks that are reserved for allergy sufferers, and nonsufferers who are willing to agree not to eat peanuts while sitting in that particular block.
As someone who suffers from a medical condition which requires me to carry my "rescue" medication with me everywhere I go,
I think that if the risk to an allergy sufferer is deemed to be significant, then they should
consider alternate travel methods other than flying,
ensure they have sufficient "rescue" medication to last the entire time they might be stuck in an aircraft,
they should wear appropriate clothing / face masks to minimize exposed skin and inhalation risk.
Requiring other passengers to forgo their "right" to eat peanuts so as to accommodate the "right" of allergy sufferers to fly seems a bit much,
particularly if the allergy sufferers don't fly often, anyway."

cqs.cq: Should the airline industry prioritize accommodating peanut-allergic passengers by setting aside reserved seating blocks over allowing passengers to freely eat peanuts in-flight?

Do you believe that requiring airlines to ban peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation is an overreach, especially considering the potential for allergy sufferers to take alternative travel methods or take necessary precautions to minimize exposure risks?
Should airlines prioritize accommodating peanut-allergic passengers by segregating seating blocks or should they rely on passengers to take personal precautions to minimize exposure risks?

Does banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation unfairly infringe on the rights of non-allergy sufferers, particularly when alternative accommodations for allergy sufferers could be made through voluntary efforts of airlines and passengers?

Helen__66.input:
Helen: "they’re not able to impose the right sort of levels
and within that bracket I would certainly put families who are living with very high levels of aggression and violence, who are terrorising communities
So, yes I’d agree with that
But I would also say that there are other families, where actually they do need a great deal of help
it’s right to intervene
and actually you can help them get back on their feet and able to parent their children effectively"

cqs.cq: What are the consequences of not intervening in families experiencing high levels of aggression and violence, and what are the potential outcomes for their children?
Does Helen believe that families experiencing high levels of aggression and violence should be prioritized over those requiring assistance to effectively parent their children?
Does Helen's assertion that some families require intervention, while others need help to become effective parents, accurately reflect her nuanced understanding of family dynamics?

Does Helen's suggestion that families who are terrorising communities need intervention while others who are struggling with parenting need help, suggest a nuanced approach to addressing family violence?

17th: "They should get the coverage
They are here
they work
they are a part of this society
Fuck off with your xenophobia"

AFCHF_154.input:
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: Should the DOT's maximum tarmac delay trigger be applied to all airlines and classes of aircraft, requiring airlines to make a legal commitment (contract of carriage) and allowing passengers to deplane during gate holds, but requiring them to remain in the immediate area?

Should the DOT set a maximum tarmac delay trigger that applies to all airlines and all classes of aircraft, and would this measure effectively address the concerns of passengers during prolonged gate holds?

Should the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) set a maximum tarmac delay trigger, and should it apply to all airlines and all classes of aircraft, or should airlines be allowed to deplane passengers during gate holds, but require them to remain in the immediate area?

Would requiring airlines to make a legal commitment (contract of carriage) and allowing passengers to deplane during gate holds, but requiring them to remain in the immediate area, effectively address the issue of tarmac delays without CBP screening, while also ensuring the rights of military members who have done this during overseas contract flights?

AK-traveler_186.input:
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: Would the airline industry's practice of charging for items necessary due to factors out of passengers' control lead to increased passenger health issues and decreased airline profitability?

Should airlines be allowed to charge exorbitant fees for carrying pets on board, considering the potential health implications and the lack of space for passengers to exercise and prevent deep vein thrombosis?

AllergyDad_200.input:
AllergyDad: "As a parent of a child with severe lifethreatening allergies to peanuts and treenuts, the thought of getting on an airplane today is frightening.
So much so, that it is strictly avoided.
It is not worth risking my child's life to fly on an airplane.
A recent study reveals that 1 in 3 airplane reactions was anaphylaxis
(Allergic Living Magazine).
I don't like those odds.
The substitution of cashews, walnuts, or other tree nuts is not a viable option,
as they pose the same risks as peanuts.
A large number of people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts,
plus they are typically processed in a plant that also processes peanuts.
If there were a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, it would open the world to my son.
He didn't choose to be allergic,
but he is.
So true.
We are not talking about sensitivity, being offended, not liking the smell, etc.;
we are talking about life.
There are a lot of things that are banned from airplanes that can cause death to someone.
In the case of my son, a peanut can have the same result.
I urge the DOT to issue the ban,
and make traveling safe for everyone."

cqs.cq: Does the risk of anaphylaxis from peanuts and tree nuts justify the ban of these products on flights, considering the life-threatening nature of these allergies?

Would a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, as advocated by the parent of a child with severe allergies, be a viable solution to ensure the safety of all passengers, particularly those with life-threatening allergies?
Does the analogy between the risks associated with peanuts and tree nuts on airplanes accurately reflect the severity of the issue, warranting a ban on these products in-flight?
Does the potential risk of anaphylaxis from peanuts and tree nuts on airplanes justify the implementation of a ban on their presence on flights, considering the severity of the allergic reactions?

They get timed responses
his plan is all there

Antanagoge_104.input:
Antanagoge: "The airline industry can not be left to selfmonitor this.
Studies have shown that the quality of information from airline customer service department is highly variable and, in some cases, incomplete or inaccurate.
The psychological effects of this, combined with the risk of death, are significant.
Stories told by families of vacations never taken, of midair retraction of the promise by the airline that peanuts would not be served, of public humiliation of peanutallergic individuals and their family by airline staff, and of serious reactions in flight, abound."

cqs.cq: Can the lack of effective regulation and oversight of the airline industry lead to significant psychological and physical effects on customers, such as those described in the provided context?

Should the airline industry be left to self-monitor the quality of information provided by their customer service departments, considering the potential consequences of inaccurate or incomplete information on passengers, particularly those with peanut allergies?

Should the airline industry be left to self-monitor the quality of information provided by its customer service department when the consequences of inaccuracies can be so severe?

Antanagoge_111.input:
Antanagoge: "The opponents of accommodations are well aware that studies have been published in the journals of the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, not to mention medical associations in other countries.
They can purchase full text access for themselves,
but they already have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions,
so why bother?
There was a moment on the board when the moderators asked for a discussion of a hypothetical compromise position.
But those demanding funerals before entertaining even a compromise position muted that.
That is sad.
There are several others on the board with some good reasonable ideas.
It's fairly clear that meanspiritedness abounds, here
probably as a result of emphasis in current American politics on the potential for influence of minority interests and needs.
But some of the people on this board  calling for funerals before advancing the discussion  give new meaning to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority."

cqs.cq: Does the refusal to consider a compromise position by some individuals on the board ultimately lead to the tyranny of the majority, as described by the Founders, and undermine the democratic process?

What evidence exists to support the claim that the moderators of the board discussion are actually influenced by minority interests and needs, rather than simply being driven by a general desire to compromise?
Can the accommodation opponents' preconceived notions and skepticism towards researchers be seen as analogous to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority?
Should individuals who hold a prejudgment against researchers and their conclusions be given full text access to studies, despite their own biases and potential influence by minority interests?

Antanagoge_227.input:
Antanagoge: "Peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin.
This study, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," ? conducted "to help address whether peanutsensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served" ? resulted in the conclusion that "that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners. The most likely source of these allergens are the peanuts served during flights." ?
http://download.journals.elsevierhealth.com/pdfs/journals/00916749/PIIS0091674996811791.pdf"
 < this message is answering to > 
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."

cqs.cq: Can peanut allergens in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin cause anaphylactic shock in peanut-sensitive travelers, given the presence of peanut allergens in ventilation system filters in commercial airliners?

Does the presence of peanut allergens in recirculated air in the aircraft cabin pose a significant risk to passengers with peanut allergies, considering the potential benefits of air filtration systems and desensitization treatments?

Does the claim that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners necessarily imply that peanut-sensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served?

Can peanut allergens, which are found in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin, pose a significant risk to passengers with peanut allergies, despite the potential for desensitization and the cleaner air onboard an airliner?

Antanagoge_239.input:
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."
 < this message is answering to > 
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: Does the author's claim that peanuts are "incredibly nutritious" and "quite filling in a small serving" accurately address the concerns raised about peanuts being a public health menace, or does it merely serve as a rhetorical device to downplay the issue?

Does the public health menace of serving/eating peanuts on airplanes justify the complete discontinuation of their distribution on planes, considering the potential health risks associated with peanut consumption?
Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?

Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts, that they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities, that they are unable to stop using their peanut the one dragon they can't put to sleep to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?

Bill_106.input:
Bill: "I run a retail business.
If I changed my prices every few minutes or hours like the airline does or charge my customers different prices on the same day.
They would probably never come back and call the better business bureau.
And they wonder why so much distrust and angry customers.
Recently I wrote to one airline that had a ticket price of around $198. but then listed the taxes at something like $400.00 extra.
I told them it was Bait and Add on.
Similar to some retail stores that Bait customers with low price and then Switch to higher priced goods.
It is illegal and called Bait and Switch.
The airlines or some ticket sellers are guilty of lies.
Taxes are never higher than the price of the ticket.
I spend hours trying to buy a ticket without getting ripped off.
It should not be this difficult.
And one way fare should be half of a RT not higher than RT.
hey force us to buy RT and then use only the one way portion."

cqs.cq: Does the practice of airlines listing separate prices for tickets and taxes constitute a form of bait and switch, which is illegal and potentially deceptive to consumers?

Does the practice of airlines and ticket sellers listing separate prices for the ticket and taxes, then advertising the lower price, constitute a form of bait and switch, which is illegal under consumer protection laws?

Should airlines and ticket sellers be allowed to use bait and switch tactics, where they initially offer low prices but then add significant fees, similar to retail stores, and should this practice be considered deceptive and illegal?

Does the practice of changing prices or listing separate charges, like the airline's practice of listing taxes as $400.00 extra, constitute a form of deceptive pricing, similar to the prohibited practice of "Bait and Switch"?

CF_29.input:
CF: "Yes, but what I'm saying is we shouldn’t encourage it for ourselves either
That’s my point.
And then finally, if I could just ask you, there’s a danger I think when you kind of say, “The poor are the ones who suffer. The rich are the bad guys.”
It is the case that some of the greatest examples of social progress over the years have come from well-off rich people, banks and so on, investing productively
Isn’t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?
What they should have been doing, what they could be doing, and what they haven’t got the nerve to do, is not loaning enough
They should actually be taking more risk and giving more money out"

cqs.cq: Isn't the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?

Does the notion that wealthy individuals are capable of driving social progress through productive investments outweigh the criticism that banks have primarily engaged in consumer credit rather than risk-taking investments?

Isn’t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit, rather than providing productive loans that could drive social progress?

CF_46.input:
CF: "Yes, but I'm suggesting that that was a political strategy, a way of covering things up
All I'm saying is that I think the people who took the sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries – and now the sufferers – of what I was saying is a policy
When you think about it now, I actually find it frustrating when I'm trying to talk to people about the real state the economy is in
And people sort of assume like everything can just carry on, and all that you need is a kind of credit based consumer thing
“Well, do we have to have cuts? Do we have to have this? Do we have to have that?”
And you do actually want to say, “Money doesn’t grow on trees.”"

cqs.cq: What are the potential consequences of ignoring the root causes of the economic problems rather than addressing the underlying issues?

Does the speaker's frustration with the assumption that everything can just carry on without consequence demonstrate a clear appeal to the audience's emotions and a rhetorical strategy?

CLINTON_103.input:
CLINTON: "I think you 've seen another example of bait-and- switch here
For 40 years , everyone running for president has released their tax returns
You can go and see nearly , I think , 39 , 40 years of our tax returns
everyone has done it
We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you 're under audit
you 've got to ask yourself , why wo n't he release his tax returns ?
there may be a couple of reasons
First , maybe he 's not as rich as he says he is
Second , maybe he 's not as charitable as he claims to be
maybe he does n't want the American people , all of you watching tonight , to know that he 's paid nothing in federal taxes
the only years that anybody 's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license
they showed he did n't pay any federal income tax"

cqs.cq: Why does Clinton's decision not to release his tax returns for the majority of his life suggest that he may be hiding something, such as being less wealthy or charitable than he claims?
Does the lack of publicly available tax returns for President Clinton raise concerns about his financial transparency and charitable claims?

Is it possible that the lack of publicly available tax returns for Donald Trump is due to his potential lack of charitable contributions and not his financial situation?

CLINTON_123_1.input:
CLINTON: "Race remains a significant challenge in our country
Unfortunately, race still determines too much
often determines where people live
determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get,
it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system
We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte
we've got to do several things at the same time
We have to restore trust between communities and the police
We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary
Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law
Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods
I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform"

cqs.cq: Does the lack of trust between communities and the police contribute to the persistence of racial disparities in the criminal justice system?
What specific policy reforms does the former President Clinton propose to address the systemic issues of racial bias in law enforcement and the criminal justice system?
How does President Clinton's call for criminal justice reform align with the historical context of racial tensions and police brutality in the United States?
Does the President's emphasis on restoring trust between communities and the police adequately address the systemic issues that perpetuate racial disparities in law enforcement?

CLINTON_123_2.input:
CLINTON: "I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system
we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform
we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal
we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them
The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together
we have to do two things
We have to restore trust
We have to work with the police
We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them
we have to tackle the plague of gun violence
which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today"

cqs.cq: What role do police officers play in contributing to or alleviating the plague of gun violence in communities, particularly in relation to the president's claims that there are many good, brave police officers who equally want reform?
Does the approach proposed by CLINTON effectively address the complexities of the criminal justice system and the gun epidemic, or does it oversimplify the issues?
How does Clinton's approach to addressing the criminal justice system and gun violence mirror his approach to addressing the relationship between law enforcement and communities?

Does Clinton's proposed platform adequately address the root causes of the gun epidemic in African-American communities, or does it merely address symptoms without addressing the underlying social and economic issues that contribute to the problem?

CLINTON_130_1.input:
CLINTON: "I've heard Donald say this at his rallies
it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country
the vibrancy of the black church
the black businesses that employ so many people
the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids
There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up
we do always have to make sure we keep people safe
There are the right ways of doing it
then there are ways that are ineffective
Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional
in part, because it was ineffective
It did not do what it needed to do
I believe in community policing
in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991
Property crime is down 40 percent
We just don't want to see it creep back up
We've had 25 years of very good cooperation
there were some problems
some unintended consequences
Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses"

cqs.cq: Does Clinton's emphasis on community policing and criticizing stop-and-frisk policing methods actually lead to effective crime reduction and community trust in law enforcement?
Does Clinton's assertion that violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991 accurately reflect the actual crime rates in the United States?

Does the approach of community policing, which has led to a decrease in violent crime, inherently eliminate the possibility of racial profiling and its associated consequences, as exemplified by the example of stop-and-frisk?
Does the effectiveness of community policing justify the use of stop-and-frisk methods, which have been found to be ineffective and unconstitutional?

CLINTON_130_2.input:
CLINTON: "it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated
we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system
We cannot just say law and order
we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system
deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little
We need to have more second chance programs
I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system
I want to see them ended in the state system
You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans
here are some positive ways we can work on this
I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us
Right now—and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby—right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets
this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby
In a lot of places, our police are outgunned
We need comprehensive background checks
we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm
we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country
If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun
there are things we can do
we ought to do it in a bipartisan way"

cqs.cq: Is it a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated in the United States?

Does the proposed plan to address systemic racism in the criminal justice system and divert people from incarceration through second chance programs and comprehensive background checks adequately address the root causes of mass incarceration among young African-American men?

Does the Clinton's proposed plan to address systemic racism in the criminal justice system, particularly regarding mandatory minimum sentences, second chance programs, and private prisons, align with his stated goal of addressing systemic racism in the system, or is it merely a superficial attempt to appear progressive?

Does the Clinton's approach to address systemic racism in the criminal justice system and gun safety measures adequately address the root causes of the problems he's highlighting, or is it merely a superficial response?

CLINTON_147.input:
CLINTON: "New York has done an excellent job
I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs
it has worked
other communities need to come together to do what will work
one murder is too many
it is important that we learn about what has been effective
not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want
Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe
no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods
we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem"

cqs.cq: What is the potential consequence of failing to address and learn from the effective strategies implemented by New York in reducing crime, while instead adopting ineffective approaches that may not yield desired results?
Does Mayor Clinton believe that all communities should prioritize keeping neighborhoods safe over respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods?

What is the extent to which New York's approach to community policing, which has been cited as an example by President Clinton, should be emulated by other cities in addressing issues of public safety and youth rights?

What kind of community engagement and crime prevention strategies would be effective in addressing the issue of youth violence in New York neighborhoods, considering the mayor's claims of effective community partnerships and police chiefs?

CLINTON_17.input:
CLINTON: "let 's stop for a second and remember where we were eight years ago
We had the worst financial crisis , the Great Recession
the worst since the 1930s
 slashed taxes on the wealthy
failed to invest in the middle class
took their eyes off of Wall Street
created a perfect storm
was in large part because of tax policies
Donald was one of the people who rooted for the housing crisis
...
 it did collapse"

cqs.cq: Can the economic policies advocated by Donald during the Great Recession be considered a direct cause of the housing crisis that occurred eight years ago?

Does the analogy between the economic policies of the past and the current economic policies of Donald Trump accurately reflect the root causes of the economic crises?
Can the economic policies advocated by the Clinton administration during the 1990s be accurately attributed to the root cause of the 2008 financial crisis, or were other factors at play?

CLINTON_176_1.input:
CLINTON: "cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president
clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries
There are the independent hacking groups that do it mostly for commercial reasons to try to steal information that they can use to make money
increasingly, we are seeing cyber attacks coming from states, organs of states
The most recent and troubling of these has been Russia
There's no doubt now that Russia has used cyber attacks against all kinds of organizations in our country
I am deeply concerned about this
Donald's very praiseworthy of Vladimir Putin
Putin is playing a really tough, long game here
one of the things he's done is to let loose cyber attackers to hack into government files, to hack into personal files, hack into the Democratic National Committee"

cqs.cq: Can the escalation of cyber attacks by Russia, particularly those led by Putin, be considered a cause for the increasing concern about the security of the next president?
Does the President's concern about Russia's involvement in cyber attacks reflect a realistic assessment of the threat, or is it an overestimation of the country's capabilities?
Can the actions of Russia in cyber warfare be compared to the actions of a nation-state, just as the actions of independent hacking groups can be compared to the actions of a mercenary?
Does the President's criticism of Vladimir Putin's cyber activities constitute a credible argument that Russia's involvement in cyber warfare poses a significant threat to national security?

CLINTON_176_2.input:
CLINTON: "we recently have learned that, you know, that this is one of their preferred methods of trying to wreak havoc and collect information
We need to make it very clear—whether it's Russia, China, Iran or anybody else—the United States has much greater capacity
we are not going to sit idly by and permit state actors to go after our information, our private-sector information or our public-sector information
 we're going to have to make it clear that we don't want to use the kinds of tools that we have
We don't want to engage in a different kind of warfare
we will defend the citizens of this country
 the Russians need to understand that
 they've been treating it as almost a probing, how far would we go, how much would we do
I was so shocked when Donald publicly invited Putin to hack into Americans
That is just unacceptable"

cqs.cq: What is the most effective response to state actors' attempts to collect information, considering the potential consequences of inaction versus action?

Does the President's statement that the United States will "sit idly by" while state actors collect information represent a clear and effective strategy for defending American citizens, or does it indicate a lack of decisive action?

What do the President's statements on state actors' attempts to collect information and his rejection of "different kinds of warfare" imply about the US's stance on cyber warfare and information collection?
Does the President's statement that the US will "sit idly by" and allow state actors to collect information without response create a clear and effective deterrent against potential cyber threats?

CLINTON_186.input:
CLINTON: "there are a number of issues that we should be addressing
I have put forth a plan to defeat ISIS

citizen-s: "I strongly support cash compensation for bumping passengers with zeroprice tickets,

something that cries out for regulatory intervention

atraveller_82_2.input:
atraveller: "Our only trouble came with Delta.
On flights to and from Atlanta to El Salvador, I requested a nutfree buffer zone as listed as an option on the Delta website.
This request was not observed on either flight,
and I when mentioned it to the cabin crew on one segment, they began taking back the nuts from the passengers around us, pointing out that they couldn't have it because "that little boy is allergic."
This made us very uncomfortable, but at least the other passengers were polite about it.
I find it amazing that people get so incensed about "their rights" to have nuts being infringed upon.
I have a feeling that these are the same people who would be the first to complain when a plane has to make an emergency landing when a nutallergic passenger goes into anaphylaxis."

cd38_220_1.input:
cd38: "As someone who carries an epipen for beestings,
I understand that allergies can be serious and life threatening.
Banning airlines from serving peanuts inflight seems reasonable;
several posts mention the risk inherent in many people opening bags of peanuts at one time
(which can easily happen when snacks are served)
throwing a large amount of dust in the air,
which could be enough to trigger an allergy in severely allergic people.
However, banning people from carrying on their own snacks does seem to violate their rights,
to eliminate what seems like an extremely small risk to allergysufferers.
Nuts are a healthy, portable form of protein,
and cannot be replaced by pretzels.
No, being hungry or not eating protein won't kill someone;
but, I'm a vegetarian,
and  I fly constantly, often on longhaul international flights, but mainly between the east and west coasts,"

cd38_220_2.input:
cd38: "The return flight is 6 ½ hours (plus commute time to the airport);
when time allows, I make something to bring on the flight,
but if my mother is having a bad day, that's not always possible.
On a recent trip, I didn't have time to eat anything at all the day I flew home; got stuck in traffic and barely made my flight (I was the last one on) so didn't have time to eat or buy anything at the airport; and as we started to taxi, the flight crew announced that we had a nut allergy on board, and that they (JB) would not be serving cashews and requested that we not eat any nuts we may have brought on board.
6 ½ hours feels pretty long at that point!
No, it didn't kill me,
but it does seem that if JB hadn't served cashews, the risks involved in one or two people eating nuts they may have brought with them would have been extremely, extremely small....
and, NOTHING in life is riskfree.
I understand that people want to minimize the risks for their loved ones,
but you cannot eliminate the risk completely, regardless of what legislation you put in place.
If I ate peanuts at the airport, didn't wash my hands, and then opened the rest room door on the plane immediately before a peanut allergy sufferer, that person could suffer a reaction.
I can support airlines not serving peanuts/peanut products,
thereby eliminating the most likely possible cause of a peanutrelated incident on a flight;
but not restrictions on what people may choose to eat."

cqs.cq: Does the elimination of peanuts from flights, while reducing the risk of peanut-related incidents, also effectively minimize the risk of other potential allergens that passengers may bring on board?

citizen-s_134.input:
citizen-s: "DOT's objective in setting this rule should be to ELIMINATE all bumping, not merely achieve some (unspecified) reduction.
Regardless of how many caveats an airline might state in its contract terms, passengers neither want nor deserve a ticket for an oversold seat.
Bumping is a purely economic device that treats passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, like so many other aspects of airline behavior.
From that objective, it follows that there should be NO cap on compensation
and that the financial penalty to the airline should be strong enough to prevent bumping, not just keep it at some arbitrarily "acceptable" level.
The 100% of the total ticket price for expected arrival within 2 hours later is reasonable.
Compensation for a longer delay should be the GREATER of 200% of the total ticket cost or the passenger's demonstrable outofpocket costs resulting from the delay
(a) including any higher priced air ticket from the same or another carrier at the same class, and lodging, meals and incidentals at average prevailing prices in that metro area,
and (b) with the obligation on the passenger to minimize those costs by arranging, with good faith help from the airline, an alternate flight or other means to get him or her to the destination as soon as reasonably practical."

cqs.cq: Should the airline's objective in setting a rule to eliminate bumping be to completely eliminate all bumping, rather than merely achieve some unspecified reduction?
Should DOT's objective in setting this rule be to ELIMINATE all bumping, not merely achieve some (unspecified) reduction?
Does the airline's objective in setting the rule to eliminate all bumping align with the proposed policy of setting a 100% of the total ticket price for expected arrival within 2 hours later?
Is the DOT's objective in setting this rule to eliminate all bumping, not merely achieve some reduction?

darawayne_182.input:

It is not just the five hours, though that is bad enough; it is all the other inconveniences, arriving late at night, having to cancel engagements, having to call a cab for a long ride vs bus transportation, and a myriad other inconveniences for which the airlines in their hubris currently accepts no responsibility."
 < this message is answering to > 
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: Should airlines be held accountable for the inconveniences caused by their frequent flight schedule changes, and if so, should they be required to fully reimburse confirmed passengers and provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements?

Should airlines be required to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking, thereby acknowledging the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements?

JJMurray: "No, no, no!

JJMurray: "I have no problem with airlines developing their own policies vice a mandated government requirement

If you want to regulate this then insist that all policies related to overbooking, rebooking, rerouting, basically any changes to the originally contracted flight must be made available in a format that is easily accessible and understandable to the general public."

JJMurray_180.input:
JJMurray: "a classic example above.
Don't just ban peanuts,
ban everything that might contain something which may have encountered a peanut or peanut product in it's life.
Once you start a ban on one product, you better be prepared for more and more demands to ban a lot of other items."
 < this message is answering to > 
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack.
Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: Does banning peanuts from planes truly minimize the risk of peanut exposure for passengers with severe allergies, or does it merely create a false sense of security while ignoring the crumbs, whole peanuts, and residue left behind on surfaces that can still trigger severe reactions?

JW_41.input:

Javier_84.input:
Javier: "I have no problem requiring the airlines to give notification of any "known" delays within 30 minutes of when they become aware of it.
BUT, being a frequent traveler, I see all sorts of problems which are unavoidable and for which the airlines will be blamed by giving such notice with the intend that some flyers may be able to delay thier trip to the airport or even the departure gate.
I know that many times the airlines can't also know exactly when a weather hold or a maintenance issue will be rectified and that the flight is then ready to go.
Many time it can be surprisingly faster than expected.
The problem is that some flyers may then  wait before going to the airport,
but then find that the problem was rectified sooner than expected and the flight departed.
Of course the flyer and the flyers rights organization will then crucify the airlines for such poor planning.
Flyers need to grow up and quit pouting and blaming everthing on the airlines.

cqs.cq: Can the requirement of airlines to provide timely notification of delays actually incentivize flyers to wait unnecessarily, rather than encouraging them to be flexible and adapt to changing circumstances?

JetJock_156_1.input:
JetJock: "Yes, most airlines pay flight crew members scheduled flight time or actual time away from the gate whichever is more.
Eg. if a flight is scheduled for 2 hours "block to block" (from/to the gate) but it takes 3 to fly it, the crew gets 3.
If the flight leaves that gate and returns 2.5 hours later, most airlines only pay that crew either the 2.0 scheduled (if it cancels) or much less.
For most crewmembers, the notion that 1 hour at the gate, 2.5 hours of sitting on that taxiway and only get paid for 2 is not very palatable.
Whereas sitting for 2.5 hours then fly 2 totals 4.5.
It is mostly the pay structure of pilots/flight attendants that poorly designed.
Most people would balk at the notion of working 4.5 hours and getting paid for 2.
The ground delay limitation, has, well, it's limitations."

cqs.cq: Does the current pay structure of airlines, which often pays crew members for the scheduled flight time or actual time away from the gate, whichever is more, accurately reflect the perceived value of the crew's time and workload?
Do most airlines' pay structures accurately reflect the actual time crew members spend on tasks, or are they limited by outdated policies?
Do airlines' pay structures unfairly penalize flight crew members for ground delays, effectively reducing their compensation for time spent waiting on the taxiway?
Does the current pay structure of airlines accurately compensate flight crew members for the actual time spent on the ground, rather than just the scheduled flight time?

JetJock_156_2.input:
JetJock: "If we were in preregulation days where an airline was making money with only 60% of the seats filled, flights canceling due to the 3 hour limit would not be much of a problem.
What is a problem is flights that are now being canceled because of the new rule
and virtually no seats available on subsequent flights to accommodate those passengers.
If the ground delays are due to ATC, weather, VIP movement (president in the area) then passengers will not be, as a rule, given cancellation perks since they are beyond the control of the company.
If the air conditioning, and restrooms are functioning properly and there are plenty of beverages and snacks on board then that maximum number of hours should be flexible.
I would be curious to hear from people that had their flight cancel due to the 3 hour limit and how the airlines handled them after that.
My guess this rule will cause greater damage to air travel then the occasional extended ground hold on an airplane with poor air conditioning or nonfunctioning lavatories.
if the airplane is comfortable and exceeding the 3 hour limit would cancel the flight with no hotel or meal compensation, would exceeding the 3 hours be ok and if so what would be a reasonable number above 3 be?"

Mpogoda_184.input:

the airline model is one of the worst business models I know of:
treat your customers with disdain and make it as inconvenient as possible for them to use your product.
Whether it be added fees to check luggage
making it too costly to change your itinerary;
making it virtually impossible to easily use frequent flyer miles or charging an exorbitant amount to actually use them;
not getting timely notice when there are delays to flights
or, even worse, when a flight has been canceled;

Mulder_226.input:
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."
 < this message is answering to > 
Samsmom: "I am utterly amazed at the ignorance displayed by some of those commenting here.
Allergies are not "perceived"
as Mulder suggests,
and it is ridiculous and unrealistic  to suggest that people with severe food allergies "live in a bubble".
No one who has an allergy chooses to be in this situation,
and walking onto an airplane where peanuts either are being consumed or have been consumed is like playing Russian Roulette.
We are talking about a SNACK ON AN AIRPLANE.
Can you really be complaining about your rights to eat a snack?!?
My son could DIE because you can't forgo a snack for two hours.
While we could drive everywhere we need to go for the rest of his life,
there may come a time when time constraints force us to fly.
No matter how much "responsibility we take", we cannot sufficiently protect him if people around us are eating any peanut product.
We always carry an epipen,
and feel that should be our responsibility.
But, again, that may not be enough to save his life.
Those autoinjectors can only buy us 1015 minutes,
barely enough time for a plane to request an emergency landing site.
He would be dead before we taxied to the gate.
FOR A SNACK!!
An outright ban should be in place."

cqs.cq: Is the assertion that flying on an airplane where peanuts are being consumed or have been consumed is like playing Russian Roulette accurate when considering the fact that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings and people can be desensitized to peanut allergies?

PeanutAllergy_232.input:
PeanutAllergy: "My son is allergic to peanuts.
The last time we flew on an airline that served peanuts (Southwest) we called ahead and requested that no peanuts be served on our flight.
The airline was extremely accommodating, but there were peanuts on the floor and between the seats from earlier flights.
For that reason, I don't see banning peanuts on specific flights or a peanutfree buffer zone as real solutions.
We now only fly airlines that don't serve peanuts.
We're okay with Snickers because the peanuts are less likely to get spilled.
However, this wouldn't be a good solution for those with an inhalation allergy.
Maybe the ban could extend to all foods when there is a specific request."

PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.

SWong_118_1.input:
SWong: "My son is severely allergic to peanuts and has allergic reactions as a result of being around people eating peanuts due to the peanut dust in the air.
We had to travel internationally and were able to work with the airline to book peanut free roundtrip flights after submitting a letter from my son's allergist.
The airline did everything they could including serving snacks without peanuts, putting allergy alert stickers on our seats, and making an announcement asking passengers to refrain from eating their peanut snacks.
My son was fine going to our destination but had an allergic reaction within minutes of being seated for our return trip.
Since he didn't eat any peanuts, we gave him some benadryl, moved him to a different row, and wiped down his new seat.
We were fortunate that his reaction was not severe enough to require an epipen injection and a trip to the hospital in another country."

cqs.cq: Was the airline's efforts to accommodate your son's peanut allergy sufficient to prevent the allergic reaction from occurring, or did they fall short in some way?

SWong_118_2.input:
SWong: "We suspect that he was reacting to peanut residue in the area of his seat from the previous flight.
We may not be so lucky next time because we have been told that the next reaction is even stronger than the last.
Even though we were on a peanutfree fight, my son still was not safe because of the peanut residue on the plane from a previous flight.

SofieM_73.input:
SofieM: "the DOT got the idea of flight notifications from the airlines themselves,
so I wouldn't be so quick to discount the incentive that customer satisfaction plays to airlines.

"Carriers recognize the importance of timely and accurate flight information, as evidenced by the fact that many of the largest U.S. carriers promise through their customer service plans to provide passengers all known information about delays and cancellations as soon as they become aware of the issue" (48).

SofieM_8.input:
SofieM: "In general, I think that blanket policies on this topic would be a bad idea,
because people have varying capacities to handle travel.
For example, the first time I ever flew without a parent (13 years ago), I was 7 years old, and I went with my older brother who was 10.
We flew from Chicago to Colorado with no incident.
However, that doesn't mean that every 7 or 10 year old can handle itmany can't, and shouldn't try.
It's something that the parents themselves should decide,
because they know their children better than the airlines do.
Also, be careful when talking about "minors" flying alone on airplanes.
I didn't turn 18 until I was already a sophomore in college
Different airlines will treat this issue differently.
Applying a blanket policy will take away the options that come in an open marketplace of ideas.
If I only had one option, because every airline was required to treat "minors" in the same manner, my travel choices would have been limited, not expanded."

cqs.cq: Does blanket policies on minors flying alone on airplanes without parental accompaniment necessarily lead to more options for travelers or limit their choices?
Does SofieM's argument that parents should decide when their children can fly alone, rather than airlines implementing a blanket policy, demonstrate a reasonable perspective on the issue?
Does SofieM's experience flying alone at the age of 7 and her brother at 10 support the claim that blanket policies on minors flying alone on airplanes would be a bad idea?

Can blanket policies on minors flying alone on airplanes truly address the unique needs of each child, or do they risk imposing a one-size-fits-all approach that neglects the complexities of individual circumstances?

TRUMP: "It 's not negotiable , no
Let her release the e-mails
Why did she delete 33,000"
